    Head V -

    The Chairman: Head V - Prime Minister's Office. Amendment No. (1). Mr Inderjit Singh.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the Singapore 21 vision which we established two years ago would be an excellent guide for us to promote racial harmony, among other objectives, in our attempt to build a better Singapore for the future. Many Singaporeans were involved in the one and a half years' effort to define our vision for the future and the House also spent two days debating and accepting the principles of the S21 vision. Perhaps, many of us had high expectations of how the S21 vision would be implemented in an attempt to get to the ideals that we define. To many of us, the S21 vision has today been relegated to something like an on-going courtesy or keep Singapore clean campaign. We need to revive the implementation of the many actions identified within the S21 vision that was developed.

    While we have done many things to achieve physical integration of the various ethnic groups in Singapore through policies like the Housing and Development Board housing policies, more could be done in trying to achieve true emotional integration or bonding amongst all races. We need to urgently build this bonding and trust among the various races through concrete programmes focused on emotional integration. This is even more important in our schools where children have the greatest opportunity to interact and

Column: 703

learn about each other. Practices in some schools to segregate students into classes according to the mother tongue option they study are very detrimental to our efforts to integrate Singaporeans. Some schools do it for administrative convenience, but the convenience is causing tremendous damage with respect to building a cohesive multi-racial Singapore.

    Sir, the ethnic-based self-help groups have achieved limited success, but much needs to be done. While improvements have been made in primary schools, in the secondary schools, problems still exist. A higher proportion of Indians and Malays go to the Normal and Normal (Technical) streams, as compared to the national average. Performance of Indian and Malay students at the "O" and "A" levels also did not significantly improve if we compare to the progress made by the Chinese community.

    The second issue with the ethnic-based self-help groups is that we intentionally segregate and differentiate our children according to the races when it comes to helping them to improve themselves. We give our children the impression that people of their own kind are the only ones who care and will help them. For the smaller ethnic groups like the Indians and the Eurasians, such an approach immediately puts them at a disadvantage simply because they have less resources to mobilise, especially in fund-raising, to support their activities. While each of them do go to people of other races for funds, the proportion of funds that come from other races is very small, compared to the total sums that they collect. Because of the lack of appropriate resources, there is a limitation as to what they can do and to the quality of programmes that they can execute. This, perhaps, can explain why the Indians and Malays still have a long way to go to catch up with the national average of performance at the landmark examinations. This is a very dangerous trend, especially in the practice of meritocracy.

Column: 704



    I fully believe in and support the meritocratic practice in Singapore, but when such a practice is based on academic performance and when the ethnic minorities are the ones that perform worse than the majority ethnic group, the result may lead to a feeling of discrimination among the minorities when they are not selected for key Government positions in the civil service or in the uniformed service. I therefore urge the Prime Minister to seriously consider restructuring the ethnic-based self-help group concept to one that more effectively gives equal opportunities for improvement to all races.

    It is about time that we merged the various ethnic-based self-help groups into one, or to create an umbrella body which oversees all the ethnic-based self-help groups. One possibility is to consolidate certain activities, like fund-raising, administration and others that make sense from each of these groups, while keeping the operational arms of each discrete. I concede that there will be more success in reaching out to people if this is done via the ethnic grouping route, but perhaps, it is only this portion of reaching out that should be kept separate while we consolidate the rest of the functions for the various groups.

    Finally, I feel that the younger generation of leaders needs to do more to have frank and open discussions with Singaporeans of all races, especially among the leaders and the minorities in Singapore, to understand the feelings, frustrations and aspirations of each community so that they can be better understood and explained. I attended the dialogue session that the Senior Minister held with the Malay community about two weeks ago and could not help but notice the trust and respect those who were present had for the Senior Minister and his views. It was years of interaction and understanding and emotional bonding that made this happen and possible. Such things do not get developed overnight. It takes many years and constant interaction to develop such a relationship. I look forward to this happening with the current and future generations of leadership so that

Column: 705

the trust among the leaders and the members of the various ethnic groups and races can be built and strengthened upon.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, multi-racialism is the cornerstone of Singapore society. We have expressed this credo by striving to forge a common national identity, yet allowing each community the space to maintain and evolve its own identity. But this is certainly a delicate task, especially as some may feel that the two are incompatible. But I think that in an ethnically diverse society like Singapore, it perhaps represents a pragmatic response to the challenge of nation-building.

    Sir, one of the hallmarks of this Government has been its candid and forthrightness, both in its discussion of and approach to managing ethnic issues. It does not shrink away from saying it as it is, nor does it seek a politically correct veneer. So we publish educational and socio-economic data by ethnic groups, have GRCs and the like, and some find this candour inconvenient, if not a source of discomfort. But putting it out in the open offers our best chance of maintaining a balanced and objective dialogue.

    Sir, self-help groups are another example of this forthright approach. They have been in existence for 10-20 years and are an essential part of Singapore's landscape. They perform an important function in seeking to raise the educational and socio-economic status of the disadvantaged within their respective communities. It is easy to take them for granted and to overlook the fact however, that they are ethnic in their focus and therefore are an anomaly of sorts within multi-racial Singapore. I was therefore glad that our Prime Minister recently sounded a note of caution lest Singaporeans misconstrue the Government's support for self-help groups as an endorsement for them to retreat into ethnic enclaves. However, I was concerned by subsequent reactions from the media that self-help groups should be merged and my colleague, Mr Inderjit Singh, has expressed similar views.

Column: 706



    Sir, Singaporeans and the media are right to be concerned about the possible adverse impact of self-help groups on Singapore's multi-racial character. But I think they are wrong to conclude that therefore self-help groups should be abolished. Self-help groups tap into a certain sense of mutual help within the community to help the disadvantaged. CDAC, Mendaki and SINDA have shown that this can be a positive force for community upliftment and if we look at the statistics carefully, we will find that in all levels, there has been an improvement, even relatively speaking, over the last 10 years or so.

    However, there is always the risk that it can easily degenerate into an ugly form of parochialism and segmented thinking. In essence, self-help groups operate in the penumbra between perfect integration on the one hand and ethnic segregation on the other. But does that mean we abolish them? I think not. Merging self-help groups will not guarantee a multi-racial utopia, yet, we would deny ourselves an effective vehicle to help the disadvantaged. Besides, there are hundreds of other clans, religious and community groups that will continue to exist that we cannot and we should not remove by Government fiat. However, I do believe Singaporeans are justified in wanting to know whether there are measures in place to curb the possibility that self-help group activities might be inconsistent with our national objectives. This is especially so given that self-help groups receive substantial support from Government in the form of financial and other resources. And it is important to know that these are applied in a manner consistent with our overarching national objective.

    Sir, in that regard, I would like to ask whether there is a case for an oversight or coordinating body for self-help groups under the Prime Minister's Office, not a wholesale integration, but a body that can receive reports, be well-apprised of the activities of the self-help groups and use moral suasion on occasions when necessary. I think this would go a long way in reassuring Singaporeans that we

Column: 707

have these entities which serve a useful social purpose, we recognise that they might, on occasions, go off from a tangent but that we have the measures in place to curb those instincts. Apart from this audit function, I think the self-help groups themselves might welcome such an oversight or coordinating body as it would serve as an important point of liaison between them and the various Government Ministries and agencies in order to launch coordinated efforts targeted at specific issues within the communities.

    I would like the Prime Minister's Office to comment on this and the Prime Minister to comment whether he feels that such a coordinating body is necessary and whether such a body can then be set up.

    Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, there are Singaporeans who still wonder today why after more than 35 years of harmonious co-existence amongst the various races, the recent public discussions, especially on the recent Malay-Muslim issues, seem to suggest that we are having a more fragile state of race relations in Singapore.

    Many, I think, have been lulled into thinking these issues are mainly related to our past, the historical baggage that our older generation carries. Younger Singaporeans, however, must be aware that they also need to better understand and manage the diversity of race, language and religion, not only in terms of our past experience, but how they will handle newer issues that will have ethnic implications and how evolving geo-political realities will affect us in ways different from our past. Younger Singaporeans will have to find their own personal relevance and experience and the meaning of racial harmony in their effort towards greater social integration. I fear that many young Singaporeans do not understand that the new and emerging issues can be far more divisive and serious than past threats and challenges.

Column: 708



    People and groups are now better connected. Minority groups and racial and religious extremists can find comfort and safety with groups elsewhere outside Singapore. Already, we have seen how some domestic issues like education brought about reaction from people outside Singapore. What about issues that are potentially more divisive? For example, what if the digital divide that we talk about would also divide us along racial and ethnic lines? What if a particular ethnic community continues to feel left behind, in terms of education and other opportunities? There have been concerns about stereotyping of minority groups on radio and TV.

    We have heard how and certainly felt very uneasy during recent talks of marginalisation of the Malay-Muslim community. There were concerns of discrimination in the past faced by job-seekers, or of older Malay-Muslims who feel especially vulnerable as they face future structural change in employment. These are extremely explosive issues which can be manipulated. Some countries like UK have race relations Acts to deal with such discrimination on racial grounds. It provides for avenues where people who feel aggrieved or discriminated by employers, for example, can get the necessary protection. It provides for a Code of Practice to ensure equality of opportunities in employment and education. It gives powers to investigate and provide for enforcement and prosecution of offenders. Other than the legal framework, it deals with how, for example, newspapers and magazines can reflect the diversity of arts, culture, even in promotional advertising. But, Sir, I am not suggesting that we have a Race Relations Act in Singapore, because I think nothing can be more damaging than to have such emotive issues being contested in court. So far, we have existing mechanisms to deal with such issues, and mainly through the goodwill of our community and political leaders. However, the essence of these provisions found in the UK Race Relations Act, I think, is useful to us, because we need to find new mechanisms to handle this in a more transparent way. And I repeat the call for setting up of a

Column: 709

multi-racial agency, perhaps under the Prime Minister's Office, to deal with issues like this. Or it can be through the Presidential Councils for Religious Harmony and Minority Rights, which can be enlarged and strengthened to take a more proactive stand towards racial integration.
12.45 pm

    So far, it is good to hear the various community organisations responding, saying that they will do more to enhance racial and ethnic activities. But it is one thing to have an agency like this to monitor and ensure that the state of race relations in Singapore continues to remain very healthy, very much like what the People's Association is doing to ensure that community centres do actually organise such activities, and perhaps penalise those who do not.

    To such organisations, we can ensure that channels for racial integration are always there and adequately protected. We can have national education programmes in our neighbourhoods - in schools and in workplaces - to mobilise participation of all Singaporeans. The multi-racial agency can also be a body to manage the various accommodation and compromises that are necessary as we proceed towards racial integration. It is necessary to deal with such issues, because people who promote culture, tradition and sometimes religion have a missionary evangelical zeal towards their own culture and tradition, and makes accommodation and compromise very difficult.

    Finally, Sir, our cultural diversities, including the role of ethnic and minority groups, are factors which, I believe, have and will continue to enrich and strengthen our society, both in culture, politics and economic prosperity. But there is no doubt that this very diversity can also become a very weak factor, and become a threat to social stability in Singapore. And it is for these reasons, Sir, I thought that greater attention should be given to this matter.

Column: 710



    Mr Simon S. C. Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, I want to join those who have raised concerns that race-based self-help groups may inadvertently lead to segregation. Prime Minister Goh has recently encouraged them to work together. I think we all stand, in that sense, between these two extremes of segregation on the one hand, and merger on the other. And we are seeking ways, like the speakers before me, of how to help these separate entities become more cooperative, so that they have the conviction about their own ethnicity, but also the willingness and understanding to compromise when need be. So I want to focus on how we can offer incentives rather than merely exhortations.

    The first suggestion I have for the Prime Minister's Office is that the Government should give funding. Government already funds dollar-for-dollar schemes for most of the self-help groups. To encourage multi-racial cooperation, Government should establish a new and additional fund. And where two or more self-help groups work together for programmes and events, this new fund would give them an extra dollar to match the expenses. In this sense, we should create financial incentives to help them work together. Exhortation works by moral suasion, but I think, additionally, practical measures to work together are important, because cooperation does take more time. It sometimes is more costly to cooperate because there are meetings, more administration, etc.

    The second suggestion is to encourage people outside of a racial group to help. They can already give funds to that group, ie, if I am Chinese, there is nothing to stop me from pledging part of my CPF, etc, to another racial group - Indian, Eurasian or Malay. I think more should be done to encourage this and perhaps Government should give a tax benefit to encourage this.

    The third suggestion I have is one of oversight. Some have suggested that oversight be from outside, from the Prime Minister's Office. My suggestion is that oversight should be from the inside.

Column: 711

Government should encourage self-help groups to appoint more members of other races to their boards of directors and advisors. These people, of course, should have an understanding and empathy of the particular ethnic group, but they will be also able to bring in some other perspectives.

    For the longer term, Sir, some would urge Government to consider setting a sunset clause to the self-help groups. I think there is some sense to think about this, because while there will always be people in Singapore who need our help, if our multi-racial efforts succeed over time, all of us as Singaporeans will be able to help them. Perhaps that is the view for the longer term, but I think it is important to prepare for that by step-by-step efforts.

    Sir, I hope the Government will consider these suggestions.

    Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central)(In Mandarin): Sir, we have been successful over the years in raising the standard of living of most Singaporeans. In fact, it has become the envy of many nations around us. However, in our relentless pursuit, like many developed nations, we will have to grapple with issues such as widening income gap between the higher income group, the rich, and the lower income group, the poor. This phenomenon will be further accelerated by our open door policy to investments, inflow of foreign talents and today's Internet-driven economy. They call it the great digital divide. This digital divide is a serious problem. Those who can capitalise on the growth of the Internet economy will benefit immensely, whilst those still lagging behind in the old economy will suffer the fate of dwindling income or stagnation.

    Unlike developed nations with vast resources, our prized asset is our human resource as our capital. We are only a red dot on the map. We know that we cannot and are not capable of reversing this international trend. As a small country, we cannot afford social disorder and a

Column: 712

collapse within our social fabric. Therefore, we place a high premium in ensuring our social cohesion, racial harmony and integration among the various races, and unity among our people. Like our world-class infrastructure, social cohesion can be ranked as one of our key pillars supporting our continued competitiveness and survival in today's globalised economy. As such, the great digital and income divide issue has to be addressed with great care and sensitivity.

    While we continue our drive to attract the best investments and talents to Singapore, those who are unable to keep pace with this drive should not be left behind to fend for themselves, or made to feel severely handicapped. Of course, I am not suggesting in any way that we should give hand-outs and welfare to those who are unable to make the leap. We must acknowledge that despite all our efforts to motivate and encourage fellow Singaporeans to upgrade, there will always be a group who will find it difficult or unable to cope. This group of people will continue to earn low wages, while the rest will ride the Internet wave and earn good wages.

    Our meritocratic system has served us well. The good and the able will be rewarded handsomely, whilst the less able will be treated fairly. It is precisely in this area that our Government should continue to play a proactive role. While we cannot and should not arbitrarily manage and bridge the widening income gap, we can offer other means to level up. Over the years, the Government has been generous by offering periodic CPF top-ups for the lower income groups and the aged, and asset enhancement through shares, Edusave scholarships, etc, all in an attempt to ensure that the less privileged and the lower income family will feel and enjoy also the fruits of our success. These are good schemes and should be encouraged, continued, and more should be introduced.

    Nevertheless, I must stress that ensuring our social cohesion goes beyond just providing occasional CPF top-ups or, in simple terms, material benefits.

Column: 713

These are not enough. Lower income and the less privileged groups, which may grow in numbers, should not be left to feel that they have been deprived or, worse still, unable to gain access to certain basic amenities due to their inability to afford the cost.

    It is in this respect that our Government has a pivotal role to play. The provision of basic amenities, such as medical healthcare services, housing, education, public facilities like parks, playgrounds, etc, should serve as a means in bridging the income gap. We should continue to leverage on providing such basic facilities at an affordable rate and make it accessible to every Singaporean regardless of their status in our society. Ensuring that every Singaporean has ready access to each of these services regardless of race, religion and their position in society is the only way to create a level playing field for all Singaporeans.

    Sir, my next cut is on the identity crisis - my role as a Singaporean. Our Government has always been mindful and sensitive in devising our policies and approaches. Many good programmes and schemes, such as making funds available for skills training, asset enhancement, CPF top-up, rebates on utilities charges, etc, have been initiated over the years by the Government in an effort to "level up" our society and to share the fruits of success. While such schemes should be encouraged, should we not be mindful of the ill effect they may impose on Singaporeans, especially on items such as rebates and CPF top-up? In fact, many have taken these for granted and that they no longer consider them as a privilege. What if our economy turns bad? What will happen? Will Singaporeans still expect to receive their privileges? What happens if they do not receive?

    A recent survey on younger Singaporeans revealed that their pragmatism and lack of passion for Singapore will make them leave Singapore for greener pastures without any hesitation. Despite our efforts over the years to build a cohesive and unified society through various schemes and programmes, there

Column: 714

are still pockets of Singaporeans who feel otherwise, in particular, the younger group. Not only have they become materialistic, they have come to expect what Singapore should offer them, rather than how they could contribute to the growth of the society and country. Are they wrong? We cannot really say so. One of the key points to note is the sense that they have nothing to do with the achievements of Singapore. They felt that they could do very little or they have no role to play. This is a real concern because many perhaps have taken the good and high standard of living that they enjoy now as their right and entitlement, instead of a privilege. Their better education and our open economy have enabled the younger generation unlimited access to information of the world. This has perhaps shaped their thinking and created high aspiration and expectation.
1.00 pm

    Singapore 21 has set out a grand vision for every Singaporean in which everyone of us has a role to play in sustaining and ensuring our success and survival. It is a pity that after its grand introduction, somehow the vision has been forgotten. While it is important to emphasise economic success, we should also not forget the very fundamental values of society and family. It is these values that will bind our people together in a crisis and to carry our nation through thick and thin.

    Occasionally, we can see such feelings and emotions of togetherness and closing of ranks among Singaporeans when we deal with issues such as the SQ 006 crash and the occasional bashing from Malaysia. We can see such feelings and passion for Singapore. However, for us to continue to achieve economic success, such value system of togetherness and bonding must be deeply ingrained in every Singaporean, so that we can ride out the challenges ahead.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I have a cut which I have just missed. Can I go ahead with my first cut on the progress of the Malays?

Column: 715



    The Chairman: You have missed your turn. But, all right, make your points very quickly.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes, I will be as fast as I can.

    The Chairman: I would let you make your points, but briefly, please.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, the Prime Minister on 21st January this year made a speech in which he cited vast amounts of statistics to show that the Singapore Malays have made marked progress in education, occupation, income, and the quality of life. The statistics cited by the Prime Minister showed that Malay children not only make improvements in both the Primary School Leaving Examinations but also the secondary school examinations, and also more Malays are getting admitted to both secondary schools, institutions and the universities. As for occupations, the Malays are also getting more managerial and professional jobs. The percentage increase in those jobs is from 12% to 23% over the period of 1990 to 2000. Incomes of the Malays have also shown an equal increase. For the median resident Malay household incomes, the increase from 1990 to 2000 was $1,800 to about $2,700.

    After PM Goh's speech, the Malay MPs in Parliament were quick to point out that the Malays in Singapore are not marginalised and the meritocracy system does not work against the Malay community. I agree with the Malay Members of Parliament. While we laud the progress made by the Malays in Singapore in the areas mentioned above, there are other areas in which the Malays are not particularly happy and they want them changed. The Malays in Singapore want to be integrated with the other communities. They do not want to be isolated, like in the self-help groups. Also, they want to be treated like other Singaporeans. They say that they are loyal Singaporeans and want to be accepted in the Singapore Air Force.

    Malay youths today have to do national service, just like any other Singaporean youths. But they can only do national service in the Army, Navy and Police

Column: 716

Force, but not in the Singapore Air Force. If this is true, I would like to know why. I would think that members of the Malay community should be allowed to do their NS in the Singapore Air Force as well as the other branches of the armed services.

    The existence of Special Assistance Plan Schools is something which also causes discomfort to the Malays in Singapore. I think that the Government should take note of that and have another look at the SAP schools. When our Malay brethrens say that they want to be integrated into the other communities, I believe that they do not want to be branded as an ethnic group or a minority group.     The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Sir, may I first take all the points made on racial harmony, multiracialism and self-help groups, and then address later the issues about Singapore identity, which was raised especially by Mr Ong Ah Heng and Mr Chiam See Tong.

    I would like to thank the MPs for sharing their concerns about the need for self-help groups to look beyond their own communities and to collaborate more with one another. And I also thank them for the suggestions they have given us on how this can be achieved.

    I think we should see this problem in our basic context and begin with our basic ideal, namely, that we are seeking to build an integrated, multi-racial, multi-religious society. That is what we set out to do in nation building and self-help groups fit into this context. When we talk about nation building, we try to do it by many ways - integrated HDB housing estates, so all the races live together; national schools, common curriculum; national education in schools so that people know Singapore's history and our strategic circumstances; the pledge said every day, the flag-raising, and so on. And the schools organise programmes to teach pupils how to appreciate and live in harmony with each other through actual participation and experience. Pupils from different schools do activities jointly

Column: 719

together. Pupils take part in community involvement programmes, and so they mix with others of different races, and in mixing, get to know one another and get to appreciate one another.

    But, at the same time, as we talk about bringing the ethnic groups together, we also want the young to grow up with a sense of their cultural heritage and their mother tongues, and every ethnic group wants to keep something which is of itself. When Mr Chiam says Malay Singaporeans prefer to be known as Singaporeans rather than as Malay Singaporeans, I saw Mr Zulkifli smiling at that. I do not think Mr Chiam's reading of the ground is accurate. Every Singaporean wants to be both - to keep something of himself and his ethnic group, at the same time to have something which is shared with all the communities.

    So, in schools, in order to help people keep some of their own cultural identity, we focus on teaching the mother tongue. We cannot teach the mother tongue in integrated classes. But that does not mean we have to segregate pupils by race into different classes for all subjects, just for the convenience of teaching the mother tongue. Mr Inderjit Singh raised this concern, but it is an old administrative issue, and the Ministry of Education has actually resolved the problem. And they have told all the principals who know that they must not, out of administrative expediency, segregate the pupils based on the mother tongue classes. In other words, all the Malay pupils in one class because you study Malay, all the Chinese group also in another class, and so on. Once in a while, there is a case which comes to the Ministry's notice, then the principal is reminded of this and is asked to put the situation right. So that is a not serious problem. In general, the schools try to arrange common mother tongue periods, where possible, so the mother tongue periods will all coincide and, at that point, the pupils attend their various mother tongue lessons in different classes at the same time. And this reduces the need for segregating pupils.

    But while we pursue the ideal of an integrated society, we must also acknowledge that we are not yet fully integrated. If we want to seriously tackle certain social problems, for example, broken families, drugs, teenage delinquency, or school under performance, then an ethnic-based community self-help approach is really a practical and effective way for several reasons:

    (1) The motivation to help members of one's own community is a very strong and natural one, which we should harness.

    (2) It is important for the self pride of the communities. It is important that they feel they are making progress through their own efforts, and not passively receiving aid from others.

    (3) There is sensitivity doing social work across racial lines. It is not so difficult to motivate volunteers from one race to tutor children from another race. We can persuade them. There will be some who are idealistic, who will come forward and they will do that, and some are doing that. Much more delicate is to have, say, an Indian social worker exhorting and pressuring Chinese or Malay men to take responsibility for their families. Families have problems, parents not carrying out their duties, or head of household not carrying out his duties. You need encouragement, you need support, you need counselling, and sometimes, you need firm words from somebody whom he respects and identifies with. And if you cross racial lines in doing such sensitive work, we can easily cause offence and misunderstanding.

    That is why we set up the self-help groups, like SINDA, CDAC, Mendaki and AMP. As long as these groups focus on social and community work, they are making a valuable contribution. But if they stray beyond that to assert themselves politically, on a racial basis, that threatens the basic foundation of our social compact and it must be checked. And MPs are quite right to point out that this is a danger which we should guard against. This was one of the reasons why the Government

Column: 721

took a strong stand to oppose the AMP's collective leadership proposal recently. Because we felt it strayed beyond social and community work to venture into the political arena, and not just politics, but multi-racial politics, going for racial politics dividing Singapore along ethnic lines.

    While the self-help groups do their own activities, we also encourage them to come together and reach out to other communities. In fact, they are already doing this. They have got donors and volunteers from other racial groups. For example, 14% of Mendaki's donations come from non-Malays. And we have got volunteers in Mendaki, 11%; SINDA, 10%; CDAC, 9%; AMP, 14%, volunteers from other races.

    Secondly, the self-help groups organise joint programmes which they open to members of other groups, and they open their own programmes to members of other groups. These include tuition programmes and joint training programmes for tutors. They run an annual Camp Teen for youths from all ethnic communities. Camp Teen is spearheaded by each group on a rotation basis to promote cross-cultural interaction, enhance understanding of each other and instill values like teamwork. And the self-help groups also participate in a larger network of community organisations, including the CDCs and voluntary welfare organisations. For example, the five of them get together and they run the Joint Social Service Centre, five of them plus the Central Singapore Community Development Council, I think it is in Toa Payoh, which was formed in 1997 and has been providing family and student services since December last year.

    We have to continue to encourage these outreach activities which will go some way to prevent individual self-help groups from becoming inward-looking, racist groups, as Mr Iswaran puts it. But we should not forget the rationale for setting up these groups in the first place, which remains valid and which we should not inadvertently undermine.

    I am not sure that an umbrella body for all these self-help groups, which Mr Inderjit Singh suggested, would help, because all the self-help groups are already overseen by MCDS in a broad way, and in fact PMO also keeps a watchful eye over them to make sure that they are fulfilling their proper purpose. PMO and MCDS will check them in case they go astray. The Executive Directors of these groups meet quarterly to coordinate programmes and exchange experiences (in fact, I understand they are scheduled to meet the day after tomorrow for this quarter). They communicate regularly with one another and with e-mail, telephone, fax, it is hardly a problem. They do keep in touch. They do work together. So to add another umbrella body will only add unnecessary bureaucracy and overhead.

    I do not think that the self-help groups are the reasons for differences in performance between the different communities. These differences are the reasons why we have created the self-help groups. They are deep-seated. They reflect partly cultural trends, partly other factors. We can work to make each group improve progressively. I think to eliminate the gaps would take a long time.

    Mr Simon Tay dwelt at length on funding for self-help groups and suggested that we introduce higher matching grants, tax incentives to promote greater inter-group activities and mutual support. I do not think this is necessary because money is not really the issue. It is the will, it is a sense of doing something useful. And there are many multi-racial groups which already exist, like the PA and the CDAC and others which are already pursuing activities on a multiracial basis. So the self-help groups fit in and complement that. If we do not think that the self-help groups have a valid mission on their own, I think we should disband them rather than have them exist and then go counter to that and try and pull them to launch joint projects through tax incentives.

    As for a sunset clause for the self-help groups in the longer term, we have to take

Column: 723

the matter in a proper sequence and have the self-help groups as long as they are fulfilling a purpose. We cannot say when our society will be fully integrated. We cannot say when these specific problems which the ethnic communities have will be resolved. As long as they exist, there will be a mission for these self-help groups. If they do not, well, then we all enjoy a glorious sunset. But I think that will be some time to come.

    The Race Relations Act was raised by Mr Zulkifli. He suggested that we take some of the points from there. This is something which we can consider in terms of awareness of the issue involved in discrimination and inter-ethnic relations. But I do not think that a legislative approach is a good one. The British have the Race Relations Act. It has not really solved their problems. They still have discrimination between the whites and the blacks. When there was a black man who was murdered in South London a couple of years ago, they had been unable to solve the crime, and part of the problem is, as the British themselves have acknowledged, that the police are predominantly white and have found it very difficult to get through and empathise with the black community. And even within the black community in Britain, they have difficulties because the black community are of different groups. Recently, there was a case of Damilola, a young boy from Nigeria, who went to Britain and was killed by other school children who were not from Nigeria, black, but from other parts of the world. So I do not think that the legislative approach is going to be the solution.

    The key is for us to establish trust and understanding among the races and proceed at a pace that all the communities are comfortable with. It is encouraging that all the communities and their leaders have supported this objective and even AMP has made their position clear, and now on the record. So long as we make progress in widening the common ground between the communities, however slowly, we can continue to build better lives for Singaporeans.

    Mr Chiam raised the question of Malay progress and of integration of Malays and also whether Malays serve National Service in the RSAF. So it is both a rational matter, understanding it, and also an emotional matter, to be able to bridge that gap and gradually to narrow it.

    As for the Singapore identity which Mr Ong Ah Heng and Mr Chiam See Tong raised, this too is a matter of hearts as well as heads - long term, instinct-building, about the obligations and the roles of Singaporeans. It is a healthy sign that younger Singaporeans are asking who we are, what it means to be a Singaporean, what is our role in society. Because like most young people, they are going through a phase of questioning, search and discovery.

    Our young people are the future of our society. So an integral part of the education is to imbue them with a sense of belonging and responsibility to the nation, and to appreciate the fact that our security and economic well-being is not

Column: 725

a natural state of affairs. Our collective and continued survival depends on our joint effort, on the collective will of all those who call Singapore home.

    It is not easy. If you are a Chinese from China, you would know who you are, 1,100 million of us. If you were a Japanese from Japan, you know who you are, one race, one language, one country and descended from the Sun Goddess of Amaterasu. If you are an American, I think you also know who you are, the greatest nation on earth, a light unto nations, a city upon the hill, a certain history, idealism, a certain collective myth which defines your place in the world. Who are we? Perhaps, we are a little red dot. That is something to be proud of. Because we have achieved much together to get here. An earlier generation fought long odds to build this Singapore and our generation continues to face major challenges as a nation, challenges which call for a strong and unified response. And I think we can all feel that Singapore belongs to all of us and it is a result of all our efforts. Now that we are almost a First World country, not quite but almost, that does not mean our challenge is over.

    We have to show that this success was not just a transient fluke but a solid achievement that we will sustain and build upon year after year. And if we accept and believe that, then I think we know who we are and what we need to do. At the same time, of course, we will have to feel it at the personal level because this is a globalised world, people can travel anywhere, work anywhere, feel comfortable almost anywhere and float with the waves. But we need to anchor ourselves here and remember the places where we grew up, the friends we went to school with, our National Service comrades, the places we settled down and raised our own families. The Orchard Road wet market is gone - those of Mr Chiam's generation and even my generation will remember it. The younger ones will remember other places in Singapore because I think Singapore is different from many other countries.

Column: 726

There are many developed countries and we are almost one of them, but there is a certain atmosphere and spirit to the place which we will remember and associate with. It is partly familiar landmarks and favourite local foods, but it is also memories and associations that link us to Singapore which make us call this place home, no matter where we are.

    We have to get Singaporeans to see this. It is a generation which has grown up in material affluence, as Mr Ong Ah Heng pointed out. So their experience and focus are on material issues, not matters of life and death or national survival. Naturally, their perspectives and priorities are different. But I think a Singapore identity is developing: whether it is the pride with which we celebrate National Day, the way we stand up when confronted with prickly situations around us in the region - as has happened more than once in the last few years even at a time of peace and relative stability - or the way we group together and reach out to fellow Singaporeans when we are working and living abroad. Whether we go to Sydney, New York, London, Beijing or Mumbai, we will find there are Singaporeans there who have formed an informal network. They celebrate our festivals together, they share common traditions and jokes, they speak the same language (sometimes, even Singlish helps to bring them together) and certain cultural affinities, and they are maintaining their links together with each other and with Singapore. And provided we can do that, gradually, we can strengthen this identity and say, "We are Singaporeans first, and Singapore Chinese, Malays or Indians second." That is what we are aiming for.

    Mr Davinder Singh (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, Singapore's only resource is its people. Their quantity and quality determine whether we can compete effectively. Both are under threat. We are not replacing ourselves, some of our best brains are being lured by the bright lights and greener pastures in other countries. The trend is not encouraging. As our resources are depleted, so our edge is dulled. We need skills across the spectrum, from construction workers to

Column: 727

corporate leaders, from maids to managers. Some perform jobs which are shunned, others provide skills in short supply.

    The arguments for embracing foreign talent are compelling. Foreigners compensate for our numbers, quality and disinclination. They inject fresh perspectives at a time when we badly need to challenge and change tried and tested paradigms. They give us a profile which comforts investors. The Government is determined that its policy on foreign talent succeeds. It has introduced a slew of legal, fiscal and infrastructural measures to make the environment talent-friendly. The private sector is beginning to respond, but there is still work to be done to overcome insecurities. But this policy does not appear to have been targeted, certainly not with equal vigour, at the public sector. Is it our position that sensitive issues are best dealt with by those with a stake in the country, and that therefore, that justifies a special immunity for our public institutions?

    There are two dimensions to the issue of sensitivity. One, where the vital interests of the state are concerned and two, the protection of confidential information. But both can be addressed. Highly sensitive portfolios can continue to be manned by Singaporeans. There is force in the argument that only those who understand our vulnerabilities and have a vested stake in the country can effectively deal with and thwart threats, external and internal. But that argument cannot be made with the same degree of conviction for all branches of the public service. Why will there be a security risk if a foreigner is employed, say, as a Deputy Secretary in the Ministry of Education or the Ministry of Manpower? After all, foreigners occupy sensitive financial positions in the Hong Kong administration. To be sure, non-Singaporeans in Government will have access to highly confidential information, but the safeguard is implicit in the policy. The people we want operate in the international arena. Their marketability depends on their integrity. They of all

Column: 728

people, understand that their standing would be irreparably harmed if they act dishonourably.

    In any event, the private sector faces the same risks. Confidential information is at a premium, particularly in the areas of technology and the life sciences. Leaks can make the difference between success and failure. In the international market where we compete, indiscretion can be highly inimical to the interests of Singapore Inc. But that has not stopped our GLCs and major private sector companies from engaging the services of foreigners. The fact of the matter is that these people, whose track records determine their fate in this global employment market, are the least likely to behave badly. If all else fails, there is the Official Secrets Act, no one who knows Singapore is under any illusion about this Government's resolve to use it to punish and to make a point.

    But what of the argument that issues which affect the country are best dealt with by those with a stake in it? Take the case of the judiciary. It is, on any view, a vital public institution. In applying and fashioning the law, judges have to be acutely aware of and sensitive to, local customs and circumstances. The judiciary is constantly confronted with, and has to address, questions which affect our national interests. Instinctively, we are driven to the conclusion that therefore only Singaporeans should be judges. Yet, in 1981, the then Prime Minister told this House that if he was not able to get men of quality to be judges, he would, after consultation, advise the President to appoint non-Singaporeans to the High Court Bench.

    That statement effectively put paid to the notion that Singapore's interests can only be advanced by Singaporeans or that we will necessarily be prejudiced if foreigners hold sensitive posts. Fidelity is not the preserve of Singaporeans. In any case, the risks, if any, can be minimised by retaining key positions for our citizens. Ultimately, it is a balancing exercise. How heavily should these concerns weigh in

Column: 729

the scale of relative merits? Should foreigners be enlisted to help run our country? The answer is that we really have little choice.

    Our private sector is already being sapped of some of its pep by emigration and overseas employment. Foreign talent is no longer available on tap. It is becoming increasingly difficult to fish in the resource rich international waters. Other countries have joined the game. They are offering all manner of incentives to retain and attract talent.

    The solution is two-pronged: Continue to encourage talented foreigners to spend some time in Singapore and, in the meantime, optimise the use of talent in the local pool. We are doing the first, but are we doing enough of the second? Today, the best and brightest are drawn into public service by the scholarship system. That means that the private sector is deprived of this valuable home-grown resource. Some do enter the private sector after serving out their bonds. But they emerge as different people, with an armoury of mindsets and instincts which may not necessarily equip them for the rigours of the marketplace. Our top students match and sometimes beat the best in the US and Japan. But they lose that shine in the real world. Has it anything to do with what we do to our top graduates? Other countries have the numbers, so there is always enough to go around. In Singapore, we do not have that luxury and are forced to allocate what is a scarce resource. The priority has always been to deploy our best in the public service, that policy has served us well. But now that our institutions are in place, and it has become imperative to energise the private sector, we should not continue to divert the flow of quality away from the market.

    The advantages of having foreigners as public servants are real and substantial. They can replace some of our best brains who can be released to add fizz to the private sector. The foreigners who step into their shoes will bring a different perspective to public policy issues. Not having been brought up in the system,

Column: 730

they may not feel shackled by political correctness. Paradoxically, the fact that they will have less of a stake may work to our advantage. They will feel less inhibited about being frank and open in their discussions with policymakers, and candour cannot hurt policy formulation. Any misperception that our bureaucracy is a closed and cozy club will be eroded by an infusion of outsiders. That in turn will generate greater confidence in the accountability of our institutions. It is surely an objective worth striving for.

Act. This Act is meant to provide for the regulation of relations between employers and employees, and the prevention and settlement of trade disputes by collective bargaining, conciliation and arbitration. Be a leader in industrial relations.

would like to talk mainly about better representation of women in non-political office.

    More women in Parliament is actually the far end of the spectrum of better representation of women in senior positions in all areas of public service and the public sector and, in fact, in the private sector. But it is fully in charge of its own recruitment, selection and appointment processes to senior positions in its Ministries, National Advisory Committees, statutory boards and GLC boards. Secondly, current senior management, being largely filled by men, the names that first come to their minds, when vacancies open up at senior levels, are those of people they associate with, went to school with, did NS with, played golf with, and are generally comfortable with. do present themselves. But in this instance, talking about board positions and not about political office, I expect that they would not be averse to respond positively to such opportunities.
